title: Mysore painting
summary: Mysore painting is a significant classical South Indian art form that originated in and around Mysore, Karnataka. Nurtured by the Mysore rulers, this distinct style evolved from the Vijayanagara Empire's painting traditions after its fall in 1565 AD. Artists migrated and adapted local customs, giving rise to styles like Mysore and Tanjore painting. Characterized by elegance, muted colors, and meticulous attention to detail, Mysore paintings predominantly feature themes of Hindu gods, goddesses, and scenes from Hindu mythology. Its historical roots trace back to the ancient Ajanta Caves period.
key_points: Mysore painting is a classical South Indian style originating in Mysore, Karnataka.

timeline: 2nd century BC to 6th century AD: Ajanta Caves period, representing early origins of painting in Karnataka.
Prior to 1565 AD: Vijayanagara Empire period, where the distinct school of painting evolved.
1565 AD: Fall of the Vijayanagara Empire in the Battle of Talikota, leading to the migration of artists.
1578 AD onwards: Beginning of Raja Wodeyar I's reign, marking the start of significant patronage by Mysore rulers.
